<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Intro-tooshort&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Intro-tooshort (page does not exist)">Template:Intro-tooshort</a>

</p><p><b>Francis Bret Harte</b> (August 25, 1836<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> – May 5, 1902) was an American author and poet, best remembered for his accounts of pioneering life in California.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life_and_career">Life and career</span></h2>
<p>Bret Harte was born in <a href="/wiki/Albany,_New_York" title="Albany, New York">Albany, New York</a>, on August 25, 1836.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> He was named Francis Brett Hart after his great-grandfather, Francis Brett. When he was young his father, Henry, changed the spelling of the family name from Hart to Harte. Henry's father – Bret's grandfather – was Bernard Hart, an <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Jewish" title="Orthodox Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Orthodox Jewish</a> immigrant who flourished as a merchant, becoming one of the founders of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kanfer_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kanfer-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Scharnhorst_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scharnhorst-4">[4]</a></sup> Later, Francis preferred to be known by his middle name, but he spelled it with only one "t", becoming Bret Harte.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a>
</p><p>An avid reader as a boy, Harte published his first work at age 11, a satirical poem titled "Autumn Musings," now lost. Rather than attracting praise, the poem resulted in his family's ridicule. As an adult, he recalled to a friend, "Such a shock was their ridicule to me that I wonder that I ever wrote another line of verse."<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> 
</p><p>His formal schooling ended when he was 13 in 1849.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-6">[6]</a></sup> He moved to California in 1853, later working there in a number of capacities, including miner, teacher, messenger, and journalist. He spent part of his life in the northern California coastal town of Union (now <a href="/wiki/Arcata" title="Arcata" class="mw-redirect">Arcata</a>), a settlement on <a href="/wiki/Humboldt_Bay_(United_States)" title="Humboldt Bay (United States)" class="mw-redirect">Humboldt Bay</a> that was established as a provisioning center for mining camps in the interior.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=1860_Wiyot_Massacre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1860 Wiyot Massacre (page does not exist)">1860 massacre</a> of between 80 and 200 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wiyot_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wiyot people (page does not exist)">Wiyots</a> at the village of Tuluwat was well documented historically and was reported in San Francisco and New York by Harte. When serving as assistant editor for the <i>Northern Californian</i>, Harte editorialized about the slayings while his boss, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stephen_G._Whipple&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stephen G. Whipple (page does not exist)">Stephen G. Whipple</a>, was temporarily absent, leaving Harte in charge of the paper. Harte published a detailed account condemning the event, writing, "a more shocking and revolting spectacle never was exhibited to the eyes of a Christian and civilized people. Old women wrinkled and decrepit lay weltering in blood, their brains dashed out and dabbled with their long grey hair. Infants scarcely a span long, with their faces cloven with hatchets and their bodies ghastly with wounds." After he published the editorial, his life was threatened and he was forced to flee one month later. Harte quit his job and moved to San Francisco, where an anonymous letter published in a city paper is attributed to him, describing widespread community approval of the massacre. In addition, no one was ever brought to trial, despite the evidence of a planned attack and references to specific individuals, including a rancher named Larabee and other members of the unofficial militia called the Humboldt Volunteers.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BretHarte-PaintedIn1884ByJohnPettie(1839-1893).jpg" title="File:BretHarte-PaintedIn1884ByJohnPettie(1839-1893).jpg">File:BretHarte-PaintedIn1884ByJohnPettie(1839-1893).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Portrait of Bret Harte – oil painting by <a href="/wiki/John_Pettie" title="John Pettie">John Pettie</a>(1884)<sup id="cite_ref-Painting_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Painting-8">[8]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Harte married Anna Griswold on August 11, 1862, in <a href="/wiki/San_Rafael,_California" title="San Rafael, California">San Rafael, California</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> From the start, the marriage was rocky. Some suggested she was handicapped by extreme jealousy while an early biographer of Harte, Henry C. Merwin, privately concluded that she was "almost impossible to live with".<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Harte's first literary efforts, including poetry and prose, appeared in <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Californian_(1860s_newspaper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Californian (1860s newspaper) (page does not exist)"><i>The Californian</i></a>, an early <a href="/wiki/Literary_magazine" title="Literary magazine">literary journal</a> edited by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Henry_Webb&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Henry Webb (page does not exist)">Charles Henry Webb</a>. In 1868 he became editor of <i>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Overland_Monthly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Overland Monthly (page does not exist)">Overland Monthly</a></i>, another new literary magazine, but this one more in tune with the pioneering spirit of excitement in California. His story, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Luck_of_Roaring_Camp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Luck of Roaring Camp (page does not exist)">The Luck of Roaring Camp</a>", appeared in the magazine's second issue, propelling Harte to nationwide fame.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a>
</p><p>When word of <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a>' death reached Harte in July 1870, he immediately sent a dispatch across the bay to San Francisco to hold back the forthcoming publication of his <i>Overland Monthly</i> for twenty-four hours, so that he could compose the poetic tribute, "Dickens in Camp". This work is considered by many of Harte's admirers as his verse masterpiece, for its evident sincerity, the depth of feeling it displays, and the unusual quality of its poetic expression.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a>
</p><p>Determined to pursue his literary career, in 1871 he traveled back East with his family, to New York and eventually to Boston, where he contracted with the publisher of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Atlantic_Monthly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Atlantic Monthly (page does not exist)">The Atlantic Monthly</a></i> for an annual salary of $10,000, "an unprecedented sum at the time."<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>  His popularity waned, however, and by the end of 1872 he was without a publishing contract and increasingly desperate.  He spent the next few years struggling to publish new work (or republish old), delivering lectures about the gold rush, and even selling an advertising jingle to a soap company.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a>
</p><p>In 1878 Harte was appointed to the position of United States Consul in the town of <a href="/wiki/Krefeld" title="Krefeld">Krefeld</a>, Germany, and then to <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a> in 1880. In 1885 he settled in London. During the twenty-four years he spent in Europe, he never abandoned writing, and maintained a prodigious output of stories that retained the freshness of his earlier work. He died in <a href="/wiki/Camberley" title="Camberley">Camberley</a>, England, in 1902 of throat cancer and is buried at <a href="/wiki/Frimley" title="Frimley">Frimley</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>His wife, by then known as Anna Bret Harte, died on August 2, 1920. Despite being married for nearly forty years, the couple lived together for only sixteen of those years.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Criticism">Criticism</span></h2>
<p>In his <i>Round the World</i>, <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie" title="Andrew Carnegie">Andrew Carnegie</a> praised Bret Harte as uniquely American:
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Bquote&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Bquote (page does not exist)">Template:Bquote</a>
</p><p>Writing in his autobiography four years after Harte's death, however, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Twain" title="Mark Twain">Mark Twain</a> characterized him and his writing as insincere. Twain criticized the miners' dialect used by Harte, claiming it never existed outside of his imagination. Twain accused Harte of borrowing money from his friends with no intent to repay and of financially abandoning his wife and children. He referred repeatedly to Harte as "The Immortal Bilk."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Dramatic_and_musical_adaptations_of_Harte.27s_work">Dramatic and musical adaptations of Harte's work</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> Several film versions of "<a href="/wiki/The_Outcasts_of_Poker_Flat" title="The Outcasts of Poker Flat">The Outcasts of Poker Flat</a>" have been made, including one in 1937 with <a href="/wiki/Preston_Foster" title="Preston Foster">Preston Foster</a> and another in 1952 with <a href="/wiki/Dale_Robertson" title="Dale Robertson">Dale Robertson</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Tennessee%27s_Partner" title="Tennessee's Partner">Tennessee's Partner</a></i> (1955) with <a href="/wiki/John_Payne_(actor)" title="John Payne (actor)">John Payne</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> was based on a story of the same name. <a href="/wiki/Paddy_Chayefsky" title="Paddy Chayefsky">Paddy Chayefsky</a>'s treatment of the film version of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Paint_Your_Wagon_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paint Your Wagon (film) (page does not exist)">Paint Your Wagon</a></i> seems to borrow from "Tennessee's Partner": two close friends – one named "Pardner" – share the same woman. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spaghetti_western&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spaghetti western (page does not exist)">spaghetti western</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Four_of_the_Apocalypse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Four of the Apocalypse (page does not exist)">Four of the Apocalypse</a></i> is based on "The Outcasts of Poker Flat" and "The Luck of Roaring Camp". 
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/USSR" title="USSR" class="mw-redirect">Soviet</a> movie <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Armed_and_Very_Dangerous&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Armed and Very Dangerous (page does not exist)">Armed and Very Dangerous</a></i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Language_with_name&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Language with name (page does not exist)">Template:Language with name</a>, 1977) is based on <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Gabriel_Conroy_(novel)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gabriel Conroy (novel) (page does not exist)">Gabriel Conroy</a></i> novel and another Harte's stories.
</li>
<li>Operas based on "The Outcasts of Poker Flat" include those by <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Adler_(composer)" title="Samuel Adler (composer)">Samuel Adler</a><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> and by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stanford_Beckler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stanford Beckler (page does not exist)">Stanford Beckler</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_works">Other works</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BretHarteGravestoneFrimley.jpg" title="File:BretHarteGravestoneFrimley.jpg">File:BretHarteGravestoneFrimley.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Bret Harte's gravestone in the churchyard of St Peter's Church, <a href="/wiki/Frimley" title="Frimley">Frimley</a>, Surrey, England</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BretHarteGravestoneInscriptionFrimley.jpg" title="File:BretHarteGravestoneInscriptionFrimley.jpg">File:BretHarteGravestoneInscriptionFrimley.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Inscription on gravestone: <i>"Death shall reap the braver harvest."</i></div></div></div>
<ul>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Tales_of_the_Argonauts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Tales of the Argonauts (page does not exist)">The Tales of the Argonauts</a></i>, a volume of short sketches published in 1875
</li>
<li> <i>Plain Language from Truthful James</i>, known also as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Heathen_Chinee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Heathen Chinee (page does not exist)">The Heathen Chinee</a></i>, was a satire of racial prejudice in northern California, but was embraced by the American public as a mockery of Chinese immigrants, and shaped anti-Chinese sentiment more than any other work at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-Scharnhorst_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Scharnhorst-4">[4]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <i><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://gaslight.mtroyal.ca/stolncgr.htm">The Stolen Cigar-Case</a></i>, featuring ace detective <a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">"Hemlock Jones"</a>, was praised by <a href="/wiki/Ellery_Queen" title="Ellery Queen">Ellery Queen</a> as "probably the best parody of Sherlock Holmes ever written".<sup id="cite_ref-Davies_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davies-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <i><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bartleby.com/102/199.html">The Society upon the Stanislaus</a></i> is a tragicomic poem, like <i>Plain Language from Truthful James</i> set in the northern California mining camps, and told by the same narrator, "Truthful James."
</li>
<li> <i>Nord-Amerika, seine Städte und Naturwunder, sein Land und seine Leute</i> was authored by Austrian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ernst_von_Hesse-Wartegg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ernst von Hesse-Wartegg (page does not exist)">Ernst von Hesse-Wartegg</a>, with contributions by others including Harte.
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bohemian_Club#Bret_Harte_Memorial" title="Bohemian Club">Bret Harte Memorial</a> in San Francisco<sup id="cite_ref-SOS_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SOS-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Bret Harte High School in <a href="/wiki/Angels_Camp,_California" title="Angels Camp, California">Angels Camp, California</a> is named after him.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Lane in <a href="/wiki/Humboldt_Hill,_California" title="Humboldt Hill, California">Humboldt Hill, California</a>.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Elementary School in Chicago, Illinois
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Preparatory Middle School (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Vermont_Vista,_Los_Angeles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vermont Vista, Los Angeles (page does not exist)">Vermont Vista</a>) <a href="/w/index.php?title=South_Los_Angeles,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="South Los Angeles, California (page does not exist)">South Los Angeles, California</a> 
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bret_Harte_Middle_School_(San_Jose,_California)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bret Harte Middle School (San Jose, California) (page does not exist)">Bret Harte Middle School</a> in <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">San Jose, California</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bret_Harte_Middle_School_(Oakland,_California)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bret Harte Middle School (Oakland, California) (page does not exist)">Bret Harte Middle School</a> in <a href="/wiki/Oakland,_California" title="Oakland, California">Oakland, California</a>
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Middle School in <a href="/wiki/Hayward,_California" title="Hayward, California">Hayward, California</a>
</li>
<li>Bret Harte High School in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Altaville,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Altaville, California (page does not exist)">Altaville, California</a> is named after him and celebrated its 100th anniversary in 2005
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Elementary in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cherry_Hill,_New_Jersey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cherry Hill, New Jersey (page does not exist)">Cherry Hill, New Jersey</a>
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Elementary in <a href="/wiki/Sacramento,_California" title="Sacramento, California">Sacramento, California</a>
</li>
<li>A community called <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Shores_of_Poker_Flat,_California&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Shores of Poker Flat, California (page does not exist)">The Shores of Poker Flat, California</a> claims to have been the location of Poker Flat, although it is usually accepted that the story takes place further north.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Road in <a href="/wiki/Frimley" title="Frimley">Frimley</a> (the town in which Harte was buried) is named after him.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Place in San Francisco, California is named after him.
</li>
<li>In 1987 he appeared on a $5 <a href="/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service" title="United States Postal Service">U.S.</a> Postage stamp, as part of the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Americans_series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Americans series (page does not exist)">Great Americans series</a>" of issues.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Lane, Bret Harte Road, and Harte Ave in <a href="/wiki/San_Rafael,_California" title="San Rafael, California">San Rafael, California</a>.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Road in <a href="/wiki/Berkeley,_California" title="Berkeley, California">Berkeley, California</a>.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Road in <a href="/wiki/Redwood_City,_California" title="Redwood City, California">Redwood City, California</a>.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Road in <a href="/wiki/Angels_Camp,_California" title="Angels Camp, California">Angels Camp, California</a>.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Road and Bret Harte Drive in <a href="/wiki/Murphys,_California" title="Murphys, California">Murphys, California</a>.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte House, at <a href="/wiki/Humboldt_State_University" title="Humboldt State University">Humboldt State University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Arcata,_California" title="Arcata, California">Arcata, California</a>.
</li>
<li>Bret Harte Park in <a href="/wiki/Danville,_California" title="Danville, California">Danville, California</a>.
</li>
<li>The town of <a href="/wiki/Twain_Harte,_California" title="Twain Harte, California">Twain Harte, California</a>, is named after Mark Twain and Bret Harte.
</li>
<li> The <a href="/wiki/Beulah_(band)" title="Beulah (band)">Beulah</a> song "Ballad of the Lonely Argonaut" references "The Luck of Roaring Camp" and "Outcasts of Poker Flat" and asks, "How does it feel to roam this land like Harte and Twain did?"
</li>
<li>Designed in 1875 by Karl L. Müller, a vessel bearing the name <i>Heathen Chinee pitcher</i> was manufactured by Union Porcelain Works. The vessel is elaborately decorated with depictions of Bill Nye and Ah Sin, the character's featured in Harte's poem, as well as the Flemish King <a href="/wiki/Gambrinus" title="Gambrinus">Gambrinus</a>, an official patron saint of beer and <a href="/wiki/Brother_Jonathan" title="Brother Jonathan">Brother Jonathan</a>, the forerunner of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Uncle_Sam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Uncle Sam (page does not exist)">Uncle Sam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BMA_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BMA-18">[18]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
